learning_outcomes.description: Apply specific marketing and distribution theories and concepts applicable to the tourism, hospitality and event industries.
Collect and analyse market research data relevant for tourism, hospitality and event organisations to choose appropriate distribution channels.
Employ problem-solving techniques to design a marketing report for usage by a tourism, hospitality or event organisation.
As a group, develop presentation skills for an organization in the tourism, hospitality or events industries.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment is designed to help you better utilise existing studies to formulate a marketing report. You are required to first choose a THE-related organisation located in Australia. You must then identify four peer-reviewed journal articles relevant to your organisation, specifically addressing: (1) market segmentation and (2) distribution channels.

The insights gained from these four journal articles should help you understand the business context, industry competition, customer niche markets, and distribution channels relevant to your chosen organisation. You are required to critically review these four articles (published after 2020), provide a systematic analysis, and incorporate and reflect on their recommendations in relation to your selected organisation.

The key objective of this assessment is to learn from published research and leverage existing knowledge to design an effective and evidence-based marketing strategy for the organisation.

Please note that the chosen organisation will be used across Assessments 1, 2, and 3. Assessments 1 and 2 are individual tasks, while Assessment 3 is team-based. You are therefore required to select the organisation in consultation with your team members to ensure that all members agree on the chosen organisation as the case study.

Output

A 2000-words essay

AI Statement

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit to Turnitin through Blackboard Assessment link.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment aims to develop your ability to conduct a competitive analysis within the tourism industry by evaluating the positioning, branding, and strategic advantages of a chosen company relative to its competitors. The task is to conduct a competitive analysis of the competitors to the company you have chosen. At least five competitors have to be included. As an example, if your choose W Hotel as the main case, five competitors could be Marriorit, Hyatt, Pullman, Emporium, and Calile Hotel.

You need to produce a poster that includes the following information:

  • Identify your company and the competitors
  • Conduct an environmental analysis of your company in comparison to the strengths and weaknesses.
  • Create a position map for your company in relation to other competitors.
  • From here, identify how your company should be positioned and branded in relation to its competitors 

Output

A poster in the PDF format.

(Detailed instructions on poster preparation along with references will be available on BB. I will also explain this on the Week 2 tutorial).

AI statement

assessments.due_date:
Video - 1:00PM - 13/05/2026

Q&A - During Class Week 12 - Week 13

Live group Q&A will be shceduled on Week 12 and 13 during tutorials.
assessments.task_description:
The assessment requires you to develop a comprehensive marketing report addressing the chosen organisation’s: (1) target segments, (2) distribution channels, (3) competition, and (4) sustainability performance. It requires a comprehensive understanding of your organisation and the THE industry more broadly.

Assessment 3 consists of two components. Part A is a recorded group presentation, due on 13 May 2026. Part B is an interactive oral assessment, in the form of a live Q&A session with your tutor, which will take place during the tutorials in Weeks 12 and 13. Further details will be provided on Blackboard.

Output

Part A: Your team needs to submit a recorded presentation with a length of 12~15 minutes. Please do not exceed 15 minutes as this will make the file too big and take up the server space (UQ suggestion). The recorded file needs to include

  • PPT slides
  • The presenter(s) – each member of the team needs to present

Please Note: Part B will be recorded for marking purposes per UQ Policy.

Peer Evaluation

A peer evaluation in group assessment allows team members to provide feedback on each other's contributions, collaboration skills, and work quality, helping instructors gain insight into individual performance within the group dynamic and ensuring more equitable grading.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture - Overview

Overview of the subject, covering "What is marketing? What is a product? What is marketing research?".
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture - Overview Overview of the subject, covering "What is marketing? What is a product? What is marketing research?".

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture - Segmentation (I)

The concept of segmentation

Market segmentation is a strategic process that involves dividing a broad target market into smaller, more defined groups of consumers who share similar characteristics, needs, or behaviours. This approach allows businesses to tailor their products, services, and marketing efforts more effectively to meet the specific needs of each segment. We will introduce geographic, demographic, psychographic and behaviour segmentation approaches.
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture - Segmentation (I) The concept of segmentation Market segmentation is a strategic process that involves dividing a broad target market into smaller, more defined groups of consumers who share similar characteristics, needs, or behaviours. This approach allows businesses to tailor their products, services, and marketing efforts more effectively to meet the specific needs of each segment. We will introduce geographic, demographic, psychographic and behaviour segmentation approaches.

Data analaysis: We will show you how to run a segmentation analysis based on the IVS wine tourism dataset.

Tutorial - Segmentation (I)

Case study - use NVS and IVS data to perform market segmentation analysis.
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial - Segmentation (I) Case study - use NVS and IVS data to perform market segmentation analysis.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture - Distribution Channel (I)

In the tourism industry, effective distribution channels are essential for connecting service providers—such as hotels, airlines, tour operators, and attractions—with consumers. These channels facilitate the promotion, booking, and delivery of tourism products and experiences. We will explain the direct and indirect distribution channels.
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture - Distribution Channel (I) In the tourism industry, effective distribution channels are essential for connecting service providers—such as hotels, airlines, tour operators, and attractions—with consumers. These channels facilitate the promotion, booking, and delivery of tourism products and experiences. We will explain the direct and indirect distribution channels.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial - Distribution Channel (I)

Case study - use cases to illustrate the function and importance of distribution channels.
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial - Distribution Channel (I) Case study - use cases to illustrate the function and importance of distribution channels.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture - Distribution Channel (II)

Online Travel Agencies (OTAs) are playing an important role in tourism distribution because they provide global visibility and access to a very large customer base. We will explain how OTAs influence consumer decision-making through reviews, rankings, and dynamic pricing, making them powerful intermediaries in the tourism market.
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture - Distribution Channel (II) Online Travel Agencies (OTAs) are playing an important role in tourism distribution because they provide global visibility and access to a very large customer base. We will explain how OTAs influence consumer decision-making through reviews, rankings, and dynamic pricing, making them powerful intermediaries in the tourism market.

Case study - use social media data to perform market segmentation analysis.
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial - Segmentation (II) Case study - use social media data to perform market segmentation analysis.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture - Competition analysis (I)

Competition analysis is a critical component of strategic planning that enables a business to understand its competitive landscape, identify opportunities and threats, and position itself effectively in the market. We will introduce two key tools: environmental scanning and SWOT analysis.
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture - Competition analysis (I) Competition analysis is a critical component of strategic planning that enables a business to understand its competitive landscape, identify opportunities and threats, and position itself effectively in the market. We will introduce two key tools: environmental scanning and SWOT analysis.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture - Competition analysis (II)

A position map is a graphical representation that plots companies on a two-dimensional grid based on selected attributes or dimensions. We will use this tool to understand the competitive positioning of the chosen company against its competitors.
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture - Competition analysis (II) A position map is a graphical representation that plots companies on a two-dimensional grid based on selected attributes or dimensions. We will use this tool to understand the competitive positioning of the chosen company against its competitors.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial - Competition analysis (I)

Poster design – explain poster design techniques and introduce students to several online software tools.
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial - Competition analysis (I) Poster design – explain poster design techniques and introduce students to several online software tools.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture - Media options (I)

We will explain Integrated Marketing Communications (IMC) and the importance of aligning message and media strategies to deliver a consistent marketing message. The material will outline how rational and emotional appeals are used in message design and compares major media options, including advertising, PR, personal selling, and digital marketing. We will also highlight the increasing role of digital marketing in tourism communication
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture - Media options (I) We will explain Integrated Marketing Communications (IMC) and the importance of aligning message and media strategies to deliver a consistent marketing message. The material will outline how rational and emotional appeals are used in message design and compares major media options, including advertising, PR, personal selling, and digital marketing. We will also highlight the increasing role of digital marketing in tourism communication

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial - Competition analysis (II)

Case study - we will produce a position map using a THE example.
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial - Competition analysis (II) Case study - we will produce a position map using a THE example.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture - Media options (II)

A media mix refers to the blend of different media channels—both digital and traditional—used to communicate a brand’s message. We will explain how the media mix is not a one-size-fits-all solution and how it can be tailored based on the target market, campaign objectives, budget, and desired outcomes.
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture - Media options (II) A media mix refers to the blend of different media channels—both digital and traditional—used to communicate a brand’s message. We will explain how the media mix is not a one-size-fits-all solution and how it can be tailored based on the target market, campaign objectives, budget, and desired outcomes.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture - CSR (I)

We introduce the core concepts of corporate social responsibility and its applications on the tourism sector. We will also examine how tourism businesses integrate ethical, environmental, and social considerations into marketing strategies.
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture - CSR (I) We introduce the core concepts of corporate social responsibility and its applications on the tourism sector. We will also examine how tourism businesses integrate ethical, environmental, and social considerations into marketing strategies.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial - CSR

Case study - THE examples are used to illustrate the barriers for implementing CSR.
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial - CSR Case study - THE examples are used to illustrate the barriers for implementing CSR.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture - CSR (II)

There are significaint barriers to implementing CSR in tourism. We will discuss several key factors, including high upfront costs, limited financial and human resources, and uncertainty about short-term returns on investment. In addition, we will also explain green washing and how to avoid this in the marketing activities.

We will discuss several key factors, including high upfront costs, limited financial and human resources, and uncertainty about short-term returns on investment. In addition, we will also explain green washing and how to avoid this in the marketing activities.
